I do not know what procedures are in place to deal with complaints, particularly in view of the fact that not every member state has a police ombudsman.  It is not as if we would be in a position to ask the state from where a particular specialist unit had come to investigate complaints.  That is the nature of my concern.  We should have more time to consider these motions.  They are on the agenda for the European Council meeting this week, which is not satisfactory.

I welcome the proposal which is important in the context of interstate relations.  I assume it is concerned with serious crises such as an aeroplane hijacking, a threat to a large number of people or the institutions of a state and that member states will not call on the emergency units in other member states unless there was a crisis.  To allay Deputy Ó Snodaigh's reservations, I also assume this would be voluntary and that there would be no compulsion on a member state to assist, nor would set criteria kick in, that it would strictly be at the behest of the host state to issue an invitation on the basis of the crisis.  This is an important proposal.  I wish the Minister of State well in his discussions with his counterparts in the European Union.

The Labour Party has no essential objections to the proposal.  With regard to the issue raised by Deputy Ó Snodaigh and commented on by Deputy Flanagan, are protocols in place to protect human rights and prevent abuses?  Swift action is demanded in crises but, at the same time, the European Union and the State are very much committed to protecting individuals from abuse or over enthusiastic dealings.

The origin of this proposal lies in what happened on 11 September 2001, the type of exceptional circumstance contemplated.  The provision would not be exercised lightly and attempts to expand the capacity of the Garda and police forces in other member states to deal with major crises.  As Deputy Flanagan said, it is entirely voluntary, both for the requesting state and the states providing assistance.With regard to the issues raised by Deputies Ó Snodaigh and O'Shea, it is stated:The draft Council decision sets out basic rules, including civil and penal liability, in order to provide a legal framework for circumstances whereby member states request and provide assistance.  Under the terms of the proposal, civil liabilities occurring as a result of an action by a special intervention unit of a member state would attach to the host state.  Where gross negligence or wilful misconduct occurs, the host state may approach the sending state to recover any sums expended.That is the model under which it will operate.To respond to Deputy O'Shea's other question, police officers from another member state operating on Irish territory at Ireland's request would have to operate under our direction and authority and in accordance with Irish laws while retaining their own national powers.

The only problem is the proposal refers to the sending state recovering any sums expended.  That will be fine if gross misconduct results but if there is gross misconduct aimed at somebody or involving an abuse of human rights, it may require the prosecution of the individual guilty of such an offence in the sending state or the receiving state.  Other than that, this needs to happen.

A unit from another member state operating in Ireland would be obliged to operate under our direction and authority and under our laws, including those that apply to the Garda.  That is the context in which——
For example, if a Spanish unit returns to Spain, where stands the guarantee or commitment that somebody who abused their standing——

The normal extradition arrangements would apply in that circumstance.  I would be surprised if this gave rise to an international conflict between member states about alleged co-operation and expansion of the police force's capacity.

In accordance with Dáil Standing Order 87 and Seanad Standing Order 72, the joint committee will report back to the Dáil Eireann and Seanad Éireann that it has completed its consideration of the motion.  Under Dáil Standing Order 86(2) and Seanad Standing Order 74(2), the message is deemed to be the report of the committee.  Is it agreed there should be no further debate on the matter by Dáil Éireann or Seanad Éireann?  Agreed.We now move on to the Council framework decision on the protection of personal data processed under the framework of police and judicial co-operation in criminal matters.

The aim of the data protection framework decision is to ensure a high level of protection of basic rights and freedoms, in particular, the privacy of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data in the framework of police and judicial co-operation in criminal matters.  It is important to highlight the decision only applies to the cross-border exchange of personal data.  It includes general rules on the lawfulness of processing of personal data; provisions concerning specific forms of processing, collection, storage, transmitting and making available personal data to the competent authorities of other member states; further processing, in particular, further transmission of data received from or made available by the competent authorities of other member states; rights of the data subject; measures to protect confidentiality and security of processing; and judicial remedies, liabilities, sanctions and provisions for supervisory authorities.  While it is technical and complex, the data protection framework document is not an agreement about handing over new information.  It is an agreement establishing data protection standards and, once enforced, will set uniform and appropriate data protection standards where personal data is transferred between member states or given to an EU body such as Europol.  The document also contains safeguards about the need for competent authorities to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to protect personal data against accidental loss.No major issues arise for Ireland because we have implemented recent legislation in this area and have the necessary components of a robust data protection system.  Data protection in the policing area in Ireland has also been strengthened by the publication in November 2007 of a data protection code for the Garda.  The code was developed by the Garda in consultation with the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner and reflects the key principles of data protection best practice.  The Office of the Attorney General has advised that Article 14 will require domestic legislation to allow Ireland in a situation where data originates here to refuse such consent where it is contrary to public policy or where the third state does not provide for an adequate level of data protection.

A number of issues arise.  The Minister of State has stressed that the proposed framework decision concerns the protection rather than the transmission of personal data.  However, as this has implications for domestic law, perhaps he will elaborate on the Attorney General's advice that amending legislation will be required.  Will he elaborate on the type of legislative amendments that will be proposed?  When might we see them having regard to the large programme of legislation currently emanating from the Department of Justice, Equality and Law Reform?  In order to allow us participate fully in this decision, this should not take place until after we have had the opportunity of amending our own legislation.

I do not have any great problems with this measure except for the point made by the Minister about the data protection principles agreed by the Garda Síochána and the Data Protection Commissioner which ensure that effective law enforcement was not hampered.  With regard to internal law enforcement, there is a great deal of hampering of the transfer of information within the State's law enforcement machinery.  For example, there are considerable limits to the extent to which the CAB can share information, such as revenue information, with other agencies.  There is a need to review the transfer of information between State agencies and to ensure we have efficient systems for sharing data in the interests of law enforcement.  For instance, if there is cross-Border money laundering and the CAB or its Northern Ireland or UK equivalent has some knowledge, this seems to me not to be as strong and effective as it could be if there were not those issues hampering the transfer of information.  Are there any proposals to seek to assist law enforcement in the manner I am referring to, in terms of the transfer of information between agencies in the State?

I refer to the briefing note on the point of the European Parliament being reconsulted for its opinion by 1 April, which is a strange date.  It states that it is unlikely that such reconsultation would result in material changes to the text.  Why would that be?  Has it now got to a stage where even if the European Parliament produced its opinion that it will be too late?  Given the demand for the European Parliament to play a greater role in European legislation, this would seem to be an example of the Parliament being ignored.I refer to Article 17 of the framework decision which describes the right of access and outlines where data subjects are entitled to receive without constraint and without excessive delay or expense, confirmation whether data relating to them is being transmitted.  It sets out where application can be made and the conditions under which an application cannot be made.  The article states that in the main, an applicant is not entitled to access and not entitled receive an explanation.  Article 17.3 states all the counter arguments.  One is allowed ask on request but this can be denied for reasons such as to avoid obstructing officials, to protect public and national security and to protect the data subject of the rights and freedom of others.  Any refusal or restriction of access shall be set out in writing to the person looking for this information.  The communication or the right to that communication is waived where the reason is pursuant to paragraphs 2.A to 2.E, inclusive, which is all of the above.  An applicant might be refused the request and also refused a reason on the same grounds.  I find this odd.

To make a general point first, as Deputy Charles Flanagan said, this is a data protection measure and to ensure good standards for the protection of data as it is exchanged across borders between member states.  This is in the context of criminal investigations only.  It is not the case that a garda can lightly enter a request to find out about an individual; the request must be in the context of a criminal investigation.  I wish to make this point clear because it is important.With regard to the concerns of the Attorney General, the Office of the Attorney General indicates there are a small number of areas which will require technical amendments or additions to domestic legislation.  One area relating to Article 14, the transfer to competent authorities in third states or international bodies, is of significance because one of the rules allowing for onward transfer to a third state of data received from another member state is that the originating member state has given its consent to the transfer, in compliance with national law.  This is the issue which the Attorney General has raised.Deputy O'Shea raised the issue of the transfer of information between State agencies.  My understanding is that the CAB and the Revenue Commissioners have become an international best practice example in the exchange of information and securing details about individuals who are involved in either cross-border money laundering otherwise.  This issue is not related to the internal exchange of data between State agencies but rather it is about the cross-border exchange of information.  The Deputy's comments about what he perceives as the inadequacies of State agencies, are noted.In reply to Deputy Ó Snodaigh, the European Parliament was consulted and reconsulted on 1 April.  We cannot compel the Parliament to produce its own observations.  However, it has until the end of this year to make its observations.  The Danish Government also has strong concerns under this heading so we will wait and see what will happen in due course.

It would have been useful if we had been aware of the Danish concerns in advance of making our decision.  They might have spotted something which we have not noticed.  Considering these issues are of concern to all member states, we should aim to inform ourselves of the concerns of other groups or states.
We will now move on to consideration of the fourth part of the motion dealing with cross-border co-operation in combatting terrorism and crime.

This decision requires member states to increase co-operation preventing and investigating terrorism and cross-border crime through a series of measures.  These include the following: member states should maintain a national DNA database and share information from it with other member states; member states should provide legal assistance in collecting and examining samples for DNA in connection with a criminal investigation or with criminal proceedings; member states should also maintain and share data relating to fingerprints and share information relating to vehicle registrations.The Council decision contains other measures to improve police co-operation.  These include provisions requiring member states to share information for the purpose of maintaining public order and security, in connection with major events with a cross-border dimension, and preventing terrorist offences.There are also provisions whereby one member state can afford another member state mutual assistance in connection with the policing of mass gatherings, disasters and serious accidents.  Such assistance will be provided in accordance with a member state's national law governing mutual assistance.  Therefore, it will not supersede the present rules governing the provision of mutual assistance.As the decision is primarily concerned with the exchange of data, there are significant provisions relating to the protection of personal data.  They will ensure data are processed only for the purposes for which they were supplied under the Council decision.  Other data protection provisions deal with such matters as ensuring data are accurate, retained only for as long as necessary for the purpose for which they are supplied and properly protected.  The decision also provides that the data subject's rights are protected and that damages will be available if such rights are violated.The Council decision contains a provision that requires the Council to adopt any measures which are necessary for its effective implementation.  A draft decision has been presented to enable the practical implementation of technical matters relating to the sharing of DNA, fingerprint and vehicle registration data.  This implementing decision is being considered by an expert group.When the advice of the Attorney General on the implications of the Council decision for Irish law was sought, his advice was that primary legislation would be required to implement the data processing and protection provisions.  He also advised that primary legislation would be required to deal with the police co-operation measures.  As I have emphasised throughout, these provisions of the decision are not mandatory.  We can decide that we do not wish to participate in them.

I strongly support this measure which is important in the context of our membership of and participation in the European Union.  We need to provide for the greatest level of co-operation in dealing with crime, including cross-border crime.  It is essential to have the highest level of co-operation, including the exchange of information and data, if we are to tackle criminal gangs engaging in drugs and terrorism offences.   We have a common objective of ensuring those who engage in activity of a serious criminal nature do not find a safe haven in this State or any other EU member state.  We do not have a DNA database in Ireland.  Our legislation has fallen somewhat behind in that regard.  I would have expected, now that we are halfway through the year, that a greater level of progress would have been made in connection with the introduction of this legislation.  I am concerned about the nature of the legislation in question from a human rights perspective.  However, that is not a matter for discussion this evening.  It would not be appropriate for us to enact legislation of the type enacted in the United Kingdom.  I strongly believe in the principle of the exchange of information and the sharing of data.I am in favour of joint patrols, particularly here on the island of Ireland.  Two police forces operate in different parts of the island.  I support the exchange of information and the deployment of joint patrols in cases such as an incident that took place recently in the vicinity of the Vice Chairman's constituency, or the horrific murder of the late Paul Quinn.  The exchange of information and the deployment of joint operations are essential if such crimes are to be detected.I wish the Minister of State well in his deliberations at Council level.  He will have the support of Fine Gael as he discusses the role of cross-border co-operation in combating cross-border crime and terrorism.

The Labour Party is also in favour of this proposal.  We look forward to the establishment of a DNA database.  We accept the need for efficient international sharing of data.  What is proposed in respect of the Irish database that has not yet been established?  Is it proposed that it will be a universal database?  If it is to be restricted, how is it proposed that DNA samples will be taken?  The Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform has amended the Immigration, Residence and Protection Bill 2008 to provide that the State will not be entitled to take DNA and biometric information from immigrants.  Is that at odds with the establishment of a national database?  I refer to immigrants who do not have a right to be here but have applied for permission to stay nonetheless.  It is obvious that the provision to which I refer is not discriminatory.  It seems that some issues need to be tidied up.  The amendment made to the Immigration, Residence and Protection Bill 2008 seems to be at odds with the making available of a universal database in Ireland.

This measure is premature because we do not yet have a DNA database.  Ireland is being asked to sign up to a requirement to do something that has not yet been debated here.  We have not yet set out the parameters of this country's DNA database.  We have not debated the technical aspects of DNA technology.  I refer to low copy numbers, etc.  We should have such a debate.  Society needs to give the Garda the tools it needs.  That is why I suggest this measure is premature.  The development of a new forensic laboratory was put on hold when it was decided that Garda headquarters in the Phoenix Park would not be a suitable location for it.  However, a new location has not been suggested and the project has been delayed further.  We should not agree to this proposal until we have had a debate on the type of database we will develop, made a decision on the various biometric indicators which might be saved or stored and considered the various data protection issues in this regard.  I have outlined my objection to this proposal.  If we decide to accept it, we will be rushed into other decisions.  We will be working to somebody else's timetable, rather than our own.  While a case can be made for rushing our work in this regard, there is no case for operating to somebody else's justice agenda.

Free movement across borders has enabled many criminals to evade justice, which is obviously contrary to what was intended in the first instance.  It is unfortunate that we have fallen behind in our attempts to ensure people do not evade justice by virtue of a system that was intended to be of benefit to the European Union.  This proposal covers many of the concerns raised during the years.  I understand Deputy Ó Snodaigh's concerns.  The Joint Committee on European Scrutiny has reviewed the implementing decision on which this decision is based.  Therefore, the Oireachtas has assessed the type of data that will be collected and the manner in which it will be disseminated to other member states.  I have mentioned that primary legislation will be required, which means that Deputies and Senators will have another opportunity to ventilate their concerns about these issues.  The data-sharing measures will not take effect until every member state has incorporated into its law at least the minimum data protection measures set out in the Council decision.  That will ensure the concerns expressed by Deputies O'Shea and Ó Snodaigh will be dealt with before there are any injustices.
I thank the Minister and his officials for their assistance in processing the motion.
